title: Small S-hook Clip, double ended Carabiner style

description.text:
This clip is intended for light loads. To attach something to it such as a key - bend a leg out and slip it on.  When a load is applied, the loops flex & the hooks engage like a monkey grip - that is until the plastic give it up and the hooks slip sided ways apart - down hill from there . . . .  
A great little clip for things that need to be clipped & un-clipped to other things. Holds reasonably well, easy to open and reset, . . . .  
Scale it to be larger if necessary.
Print it flat and clean up as needed.

rculmer,
I used a Printrbot for this and created the gcode with Slic3r set for a 4 pass single layer raft along with support, both of which I trimmed off later. The nozzle was a .5 mm with .4 mm between layers, Also believe Slic3r was set at 15% infill but since this is small it is basically solid.

remixed_from.title: Clip Holder for Acoustic Guitar Pickup

description.text: This was inspired by my earlier guitar pickup: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:457172. It is built for my 4" (103mm) diameter sound hole. If you are interested in modifying for a different size, the Fusion 360 file is here: http://a360.co/1MgR28M Check out the video of it in action: http://youtu.be/2kegVcVyiuk

I printed this on a Replicator 2 at .15mm layer height with structures ON. For the electronics you will need a 1" (25mm) piezo speaker and a shielded 1/4" TRS guitar cable. Strip the ends of the cable. On one end connect the signal wire to the center of the Piezo element and the ground/shielding to the metal/brass surface of the piezo element. Connect the signal wire to the signal tab on the 1/4 in audio jack and connect the shielding to the ground tab.

title: CC1563 camera mount for Armattan Morphite 170mm and 180mm frames

description.text:
Armattan makes great frames for multicopters, Morphite frame is one of the latest creations designed for 1306 motors, 4045 props and 2S/3S battery. This thing will allow you to mount CC1563 camera on the frame securely using 2 x M3 nylon bolts and nuts. The mount protects the lens from all the sides, has holes for the camera wires and the microphone. Use 2-2.5mm wide ziptie to secure the camera (see the photo). Total weight with the hardware is about 1.5g (20% infill ABS, 2 perimeters). Useful links:
Morphite 180mm Frame
Morphite RXR Frame Kit
CC1563 Camera
RCG thread Feel free to PM me on RCG.
Let me know if you like it and want to make a small donation, I'll give you my PayPal =) This mount may work with similar cameras that have the same size, though, I didn't test it. UPDATE: there is now a new lightweight version (CC1563-sparky.STL) that can be used on micro frames. Just use double sided 3M VHB tape. This version doesn't have the screw mounts and is a bit lower.

ABS, 2 perimeters, 20% infill.  
PLA may melt because the camera can get hot (has linear 5->3.3V regulator).

remixed_from.author: PocketBrain
remixed_from.title: Desktop stand for 5" LCD panel frame

title: Frame for 5-inch touch panel from Adafruit

description.text:
In Progress! To-Do
Face:
  • Widen screw holes
  • Tweak position of screw holes
  • Widen counter-sink chamfer
    Back:
  • Extend holes through rear
  • Tweak hole position and size to match front holes
  • Add small chamfer for easy screw entry.
  • Measure depth against components on PCB for screw clearance.
  • Slim it down and knock-out vs. the HDMI port (exposed).
    /To-Do
    • Well, they made a new version of the 5" HDMI LCD panel (with or without touch) and Adafruit's selling it. I just had to make an enclosure. This works with my little desktop stand, like the other enclosure I designed. Note, I gave it some holes to breathe.
    New version has an expanded aperture for the LCD plate. Caveat: The design herein fits the measurements of the panel I have, sort of. They have the LCD portion stuck onto the PCB with some double-stick foamy tape, and it's not perfectly centered, even rotated a little. You will likely have to un-mount the thing and re-mount it to make it fit well.

begin warning
The unit I received didn't have the LCD bit perfectly aligned when it was attached to the PCB; you will likely have to remove/realign the LCD on the PCB and this will probably void your warranty. I did separate the tape from the metal frame with a hobby knife: be careful when doing something like this. Avoid touching the circuit board with the knife, and be double sure not to cut yourself; you take full responsibility.
end warning
Build it with plenty of shells, or solid. It's meant to be mounted to the little desktop stand with four #4 flat-head screws. The front then screws onto the rear panel with four #4 x 1/2" screws; it is designed to self-tap into the holes on the rear. Okay, I did print the front part of the panel in PLA (had to remove the sticky foam on the panel itself, as noted above). I used 2 shells and 25% fill, .3mm layer height and default everything else, no raft in Makerware on my Replicator 2. If you print it, post your "I made one" details, especially if you make it in ABS.

comments.text:
okay, im completely new to RPi and thingverse, but if i wanted to have this milled out of cnc alluminum, what would i have to do?
also, if not, where can i go to get this printed? i dont have a 3ds printer
comments.author: Onifon

comments.text:
You would need to export the file into a format compatible with whatever service would mill or print it. Most 3D printing (shapeways for example) services will print directly from the .STL file (included), but milling services will want STEP or IGES or other format. I might try to export it into other formats. Note that the front piece has beveled screw holes to counter-sink the mounting screws. This won't mill directly; they would have to drill that straight.
Another alternative would be to join a makerspace in your area (if it exists) or find a local library with 3D printers.
If you do have this printed out, let me know how much it cost.
comments.author: Onifon

All parts were printed in 0.2mm resolution and 50% infill for extra weight to hold the phone.  
To make this you have to: print the parts, insert the ball through the upper base part and glue the iphone part to the ball.

remixed_from.title: Hinged Box With Latch, Somewhat Parametric and Printable In One Piece

description.text: Modified Hinged Box

Here are two bake shapes, I'm not sure yet which about one works best, but we will soon find out once my daughter uses them to bake some cookies. The intended use is as a stamp on dough, or perhaps you could fill them with hot chocolate etc.  
I gave the large one the hexagon mesh for stiffness, this is what you find in the stl, the smaller one is obtained by cutting the lower end of the model.

This is a suggestion on how to make an X-carriage for the P3Steel printer (and other printers - naturally).
It contains:
1) The idler side
2) The motor side
3) The x-carriage
4) A mount for the E3D V6 hotend and inductive sensor
5) A mount for the E3D V6 hotend and inductive sensor (on the Alu x- carriage)
6) A mount for the RepRapPro hotend and inductive sensor
7) Fan mounts for the E3D hotend with and without 3mm nuts in.
8) Hall sensor mount All prints with 40% infil, on my RepRapPro. Please enjoy

After printing the parts then;
1) Clean up the bearing hole in the idler and expand screw hole to 4mmø and mount a ZZ624 bearing with washers on either side and ensure that it runs nicely.
2) Place M3 nuts in each of the holes for the smooth rods and hold it with the end of a 7mm drill bit – screw in a M3X20mm hex screws in from the outside and tight down the nut into the grove in the bottom of the smooth rod hole. (same procedure on the Motor mount) – These are for adjusting the "straightness" of the parts when mounted on the Z smooth rods.
3) Clean up the holes for the smooth rods with a 8mm drill bit.
4) Place 3 linear bearings (tow on the top rail and one on the lower rail) on the smooth rods and mount them into the holes on the motor and idler parts. (I have my X-motor mount on the right side)
5) Place 2X2 linear bearings in the motor and idler parts and screw them tight. (Note that you properly need to file away any chunks of plastic that might be in the bearing holes – all four.)
6) Mount on the printer and adjust for straightness by the 4 hex screws until the x-carriage moves smoothly up and down the z-rods
7) Place a M5 nut and a spring on the treaded rod (Z-drive) and place it in the slot. Now screw it down to it is sticking out of the other end and mount a second M5 nut that slide into the small hex hole at the bottom. Push down and compress the spring and screw up the lower nut so that it becomes nice and springy (removing tread and nut slack)
8) Now slide over the X-carriage and push in the bearings into the slots (should be a very tight fit) and ensure that it moves freely along the x-axis.
9) Put in your GT2.5 belt into the slots on the X-carriage (it might need some sanding to make the tight fit possible, only sand on the flat side). Move the belt through the idler and back passed the x-carriage and into the motor bracket and back to the X-carriage.
10) Mount motor and push forward into the "sliding holes" so that it is closest to the canter of the printer. Now mount the pulley and finally tighten the belt (and cut off any excess) and fit it into the X-carriage. By pulling the motor away from the center of the printer – you will be able to tighten the belt.
11) Place nuts (if you use that version) in the fan mount and then first mount the sensor and then the hotend with the fan mount.
12) Mount the fan
13) Insert the Dupont (3 lag) female pin plug (with wires) housing into the Hall sensor holder while the part is still hot on the printer. Let it cool and the take it off the printer. Mount this in between the belts on the motor or idler side. Now you should have your X-axis build and mounted. Mount the different holders for the hotend and induction sensor – as you feel like. Note there is a M3 hole in the X-carriage pointing towards the motor end and that is for a magnet if you use Hall end stops the sensor can be mounted on the small hole in between the belts on the motor side. Please enjoy

description.text:
Semipermanent case for the Arduino Uno.   
Features holes and slots for pins, power, and USB-B; also, a "button-button" to access the Arduino's reset button without having to open the case.   
Includes plain Lid, or Lid with fine text denoting pins.   
Uses the spring from a common Pilot G-2 pen in the locking mechanism.   
Has holes to mount Arduino to the case, and holes to mount the case onto whatever (6 x 7 cm).  
Basic Arduino Reference Model Included!  
** Please comment to let me know how your print went and if any dimensions need to be worked!  
EDIT 4/7/15: Changed length of the E-Lock and E-lock slot slightly.

Place the spring and E-shaped piece into their slot, press down and slide the lid about 3/4s of the way on.   
Hold the button labeled 'R' over the Arduino's reset button and slide the lid the rest of the way, so that the R-button is locked in place.  
Minor post-processing MAY be necessary.

description.text:
I don't like bare electronics laying around my shop, so I designed this enclosure for the Ethernet Smooth Stepper. I'm posting the design in hopes that someone will be able to help improve on the enclosure. Things that need to be improved:
How the top secures to the base
Mounting pattern for base

Inspired by CreativeTools' Universal stand-alone filament spool holder
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:508896 Made a universal roller using ball bearings before but not satisfied, so decided to stick with my scrap hard drive as a roller. After using a roll of tape to support the spool, I made this to better centralize the spool on the disc (not perfect but I'm happy with it). I made the base and the rod so tight so I didn't need to use glue to stick them together, but because of that I pushed so hard and almost broke the base. The center-guide cone works fine on the big spool, but not the small one as shown in the picture. Note:
Hard drive Spindle diameter : 32mm
Base to Disc hole : 32mm
Rod diameter : 15mm
Rod height : 120mm
Rod to base hole : 15mm
**If your prints are too tight to fit, file or sand down a bit before assembling. Update: Small center guide STL added

**If your prints are too tight to fit, file a little before assembling. After printing all parts:
  • Push the base to the disc spindle
  • Push the rod to the base
  • Make the rod rotating perpendicular to the base disc as close as possible by rotating the disc. Adjust if needed.
    • Now, put a spool of filament through the rod on the base disc, then use the center-guide to move the spool.
These clamps were made for several purposes. They would work as hands for a robot too.

title: olinux K8200 mod for E3D V6 on K8200/3Drag

description.text:
K8200 Mod for mounting E3D V6 hotend on K8200. It is made for this extruder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18379
I have designed a new extruder for this mod: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1360839 It is designed to reduce vibrations at the nozzle and to reduce noise from hotend cooling.
Use it with a 120mm fan. I installed auto levelling on Z axis. There are holes in the bracket where you can mount this holder.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:218954
I just prepared the holes with a 3.2 mm drill and screwed M4 screws directly into the plastic.
I used this holder for the Z endstop
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:262892 For X and Y axis I use a 3M belt with this pulleys.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1317061 I made a new bed heating with four high power resistors with 2.2 ohm. I put a relay between board and heating. I use a 12V ATX power supply for the board, and the original Velleman power supply with 15V for bed heating. Works really fine. I reach temperatures of more then 100°. I'm able to print HIPS directly on a glass plate without any tape. With 5 mm brim and a temperature of 80° I don't have warping. I also build a housing for my printer. The following link was my inspiration. I just changed the dimensions for the K8200. Front and back panels are 600x600mm, top and bottom panels 600x452mm and the sides are 600x440mm. Detailed drawings will follow.
http://www.3d-proto.de/index.php?p=project_printercase#PrusaGehaeuse For lightning I used 2m of LED stripes. It is bright inside with not so much shadow. Videos are here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MEE53Qg9AGE
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cLUBvlxJFgQ
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=90JOFXcI2i0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OW9QyTld3KQ The cable chain on the last picture is printed in ABS with a 0.25 mm nozzle and a layerhight of 0.1 mm. It is printed directly on a glass plate.

description.text: For countertops with limited space, you can still enjoy the luxury of a Caffitaly or Nespresso machine. This beverage capsule dispenser lets you store your capsules without the bulky boxes taking up precious tabletop or shelf space (Picture 2). And you can dispense capsules easily and quickly with just the push of a paddle. The return action reloads the next capsule, ready for your next cuppa! http://youtu.be/dgNXrUQ_gik The open concept lets you easily see how many capsules are left - I hate having to pour out the capsules from the box to count the balance of a certain brew. Worse, to find I’m down to the last couple. The set up is modular, each set of legs and ring take you as high as you want, limited by the space between countertop and overhang shelf. The standard version (two levels of rings) holds 11 Caffitaly or 10 Nespresso capsules. One of the legs come with a label clamp, so you can simply rip off the label on the top of the box, and always know what capsules are in a particular dispenser. Personalise it: Print, paint in any colour combination or pattern you can think of! For my own use, I mounted the dispensers on 1/4” plastic electrical wire trunking with short wood screws, and simply pasted it on the wall with double-sided tape. No messy drilling involved, the dispensers are easily relocatable, with no concerns from the wife that I may have destroyed her kitchen. In the picture of my 3 dispensers, the one on the right is version 1, on the left, version 2 and in the centre sits the current improved version. And that blank space? I’m dreaming of an RFID-triggered motorised dispenser ;)

• Print (per standard set *):
    • 1 Paddle
    2 Paddle Caps
    1 Dispenser Cage
    2 Extension Rings
    1 Top Ring
    3 Top legs (short ones - in 1 STL file)
    7 Cage Legs **
    1 Leg with Label Holder (optional, may be replaced with 1 Cage Leg)
  • To extend capacity by about 5 capsules, add 1 Extension Ring and 4 Cage Legs below the top ring layer.
    • ** If you encounter print-warping with the long Cage Legs, use the “3a-Cage Leg (anti-warp)” file, with added support that you can cut away post print. I use a non-heated bed so I’ve got some curvy legs now :) There is no particular assembly order but this is how I did it with minimal “argh!” moments. @@@@ The non-printed parts required:
    1 x gear shaft (to pivot the dispenser paddle) — 2mm axle about 62mm long (usually sold in 100mm lengths) available from hobby shops or a length of stiff wire, or length of a large paper clip
    1 x rubber band (for the spring action)
    2 x small screws (to hold the rubber band). Recommended M3 6mm and 12mm, or small screws from local hardware stores
    2 x mounting screws (to mount the dispenser’s wall clips)
    @@@@

  • Join the Cage Legs to Extension Rings, working up to the Top Ring (with the 3 short legs). The top ring’s “hook” faces the back, leaving an opening in front, that’s where you will load your capsules.
    Note: The legs have been designed to be tight and should fit snug, so that it is easier to trim layers if the output is not that accurate, rather than to fill in gaps for a flimsy set up.
    Note: See Picture 5, the legs should flush with the INSIDE of the rings.

  • Install screws on Dispenser Cage and Paddle, the shorter one on the Cage. Two screws of the same length would work too as the runner band is elastic :)

  • Attach the Dispenser Cage to the assembled rings and legs assembly.

  • Install the Paddle with the axle rod through the Dispenser Cage. Then cap it off with the Paddle Caps.

  • Link the Paddle and Dispenser Cage screws with the rubber band. Test for desired tension.
    Tip 1: Knot the loop smaller (or loop 2-3 times) for higher tension. The Paddle should spring back into an “upright” position, but not so tight that you need force to push it.

  • Slide in Wall Brackets onto the hooks of the Dispenser Cage and Top Ring.

  • Measure the distance between the centre of the holes (centre of screw holes are about 255mm apart).

  • Mark your wall accordingly (or plastic electrical trunking if you follow my installation choice). Install the wall brackets, slot in your dispenser, load your capsules. Enjoy!

remixed_from.title: Universal Adjustable Phone and Small Tablet Stand

description.text: The stand holds an iPhone or similarly sized phone. The angle is adjustable from about 30deg to 60deg. I designed and printed it for a friend but never got a picture of it. I did notice problem after i printed it, due to the location of the pivot point, the weight of the phone pulls the phone forward when adjusted to angles standing straighter up than about 60deg.

Print Both of the STL files and remove the raft. The small spacers may need to be cleaned up with a file or sandpaper so that the joints move easily. Assemble the stand using four 4x1/2 phillips metal screws:
  • insert the spacers into the holes on the side parts that hold the phone.
  • attach the base and the stop that adjusts the angle to the sides using the screws through the spacers.

comments.text: I made this, and it's great. 1/2 x 4 is a standard US screw size. I think my only issue is that the base is very close to the bottom, so at more upright angles a plugged in cable hits the desk.

title: Solidoodle SD4 Y Axis Belt Tensioners

description.text: Both of my factory belt tensioners broke within 3 months of owning my SD4, so I created these more substantial ones in Sketchup. They use either the original brass inserts scavenged from the factory parts (with a slight countersink for the shoulder on the stock parts) or EZ-Lok 240-M3-BR inserts after reaming the holes out to 4mm (5/32"). Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:705297 and the factory part, but ended up doing a model from scratch.

I used M3x14 cap screws in the tensioner and M3x10 cap screws to fasten them to the frame. There are Left and Right versions with notches to accommodate the bushings that hold the rods in place. If you can't find the EZ-Lok 240-M3-BR inserts locally, send a picture of your finished part with a SASE and a request for 4 or 8 inserts to: ComputerSmiths Consulting, Inc.
151 Chestnut Street
North Reading, MA 01864 and I'll send you some. They are 8 cents each plus $15 shipping and handling, so I stocked up.

title: Smooth-O-Matic Parts Polisher and Rock Tumbler

description.header: Tired of having to use a exact-o knife to clean off your 3d printed parts?
description.text:
Well then, just throw you parts in a 1 quart paint can with some rocks, wait several hours and voilÃ ! You have partially cleaned parts that still need to be deburred. err, well .... Maybe I did something wrong. I am sure you will have better luck. This is a video of it working.
http://youtu.be/GwR-Y1e6QFQ This is a great low cost DIY solution for those who don't want to pay an arm and a leg for a rock tumbler. I have had mine running now for a coupler hours. I don't know if the parts are getting cleaned but I do know that it seems to be functioning as expected. I will probably be selling the kits. I don't really know what to use as an abbrasive. I went with a bag of small gravel from home depot. The gravel doesn't seem to work at all for me. It might just need a lot more time. I think I will head to Harbour Frieght and get a bag of walnut shells tomorrow.

Improvements in version 2:
  • addition of a 3rd gear
  • a new frame
  • all new gears
  • Gear box cover
  • Electronics upgrade including Speed control*
    • *depends on if the parts come in before I am done
REV 1.0

• 3/8" x 36" Round Rod - Aluminum
  • 1 1/2" x 2' PVC Pipe Section
  • 3M Safety Walk 2 in. x 15 ft. Step and Ladder Tread Tape
  • 1 Roll of Duct Tape (if you don't already have some laying around. You won't need much)
  • 2 x BEHR 1 Qt. Metal Paint Bucket and Lid

• 45 RPM 6VDC Motor with 1/8" Shaft

    http://www.sciplus.com/p/MICROMOTOR_47952

  • 1 x Motor_Gear

  • Cut 2 x 16" lengths from 3/8" Aluminum Round Bar ( this will be a little long but will be trimmed after you dry fit everything)

A simple phone holder created using 3D printing and laser cutting that fits in the top of a microphone stand and allows hands free video calls.

The base (that fits in to the microphone holder) needs to be 3D printed. The STL file should be good for most stands, but if you need to tweak the dimensions the OpenSCAD file is included and the variables to tweak are at the top.  
The mount is best cut from 3mm acrylic on a laser cutter. The fingers that hold the phone can be bent in to position using a hot jet of air (I used a soldering reflow device at 300C) or a hot wire machine designed for such a task. Remember to leave enough room for the phone, it's case, and the back of the screws to fit. Also be careful not to cover the camera on the front of the phone.  
The two parts are attached using 4MM screws and a nut can be added to the inside for extra strength if desired. The chage cable and perhaps headphone cable can be put in the middle hole before insertion in to the microphone stand.

description.text:
Nut knobs are useful for many purposes in DIY projects. All the different knobs in the gallery are made with this Customizer. I have added some sample knobs for M3 nuts as there are most common used size for 3d printer.
The screwdriver handle for standard 1/4" hex bits is surely a unusual application, but it works great. Especially if you need a extra small one for your project. If you got problems getting the knob in place, simply heat up the nuts a bit (about 60-80 °C / 140-175 °F) and it easily slips in place. Please refer the instructions to see the setting I have used for the sample files.

Easy Storage!
This six sided snap fit container can hold anything you may have laying around, from pens to tools :D

Instructions For this project you'll need:
  • Good amount of filament
  • Hot glue gun
  • 6x hex-tainers ( just all the containers )
  • 1x HEX ( the main frame )
  • 1x Hex-clip ( snap fittings )
    • Assembly All you will need to do is hot glue the Hex-clips to the very top of the HEX frame. Make sure it is center, and let it dry for a couple minuets. The six containers slide very carefully into the frame, and sit on the little lip on the bottom. Then the snaps will fit and hold the tops of the containers. Congrats! you've officially created your very own HEX-capsile!
    Now it's ready to store whatever!!

title: grease tray for George Foreman grill

description.text:
grease tray for small George Foreman grill  
It leaked.... But I fixed that with a couple coats of spray paint.

[update 3-12-15]
Fixed it.
Thinner layers didn't prevent leaks. If there's the tiniest void or hole, hot grease will leak. So, I spray painted the inside with 2 coats of "RUST-OLEUM Textured Plastic" (paint). That did the trick.
I forget where I purchased it or how much it cost. Home Depot may have it. This paint is recommended for vinyls, polystyrene, resins, fiberglass, PVC, and just about anything outdoor plastic furniture might be made of. Indoor- outdoor. No primer required.
Painting is an easy way to seal prints when there are no other factors to consider. [update 3-7-15]
I tried cooking a half-pound burger, and the tray leaked... Not too bad, but the bottom was all wet with grease and water. A few drops got on plastic wrap I always protect the counter-top with (these grills are messy), so clean up wasn't necessary, but I still prefer it holds hot, liquid grease better than it does now. The problem might be due to the coarse 0.40mm layers. I'm printing another at a finer resolution.. 0.30mm and at slow speed (100 minutes).... and will try it again in a day or two.]]] Small George Foreman grill from a thrift store had no drip tray. This tray took 60 minutes to print, using 41 grams of ABS. Average speed and medium fill, but with thick 0.40mm layers to save time. The 6 inch long tray (1.25 inch tall, 2 inches wide) will fit on the Afinia H-49 build plate if it is rotated 45 degrees. If this STL file is tiny when imported to your (metric) print software, scale up by a factor of 25.4. (It should then be 152.4mm long.) And I suppose this tray might be scaled to fit different grills, if the printer has the capacity.

I originally designed a cup guard to keep the heat in my coffee and my pets out.  It has grown into a full Tardis mug set, including guard, mug and a coaster. Now Properly scaled for 3d printing.  Holds close to 2 cups.

There are 3 main segments to this set.  The coaster prints in one piece.  The mug prints in two segments.  Print the interior with a high infill setting.  This should help reduce chance of the mug leaking.  You can print the exterior at a lower infill to save time and filament.  Slide the interior into the exterior an glue it in place.  The cover can be be printed in one piece or in two and then glued together.

Since its not good to keep your batteries in your tools, here you go.
I haven't tested it with the larger version of the battery. But I left enough room on the outside hopefully to accommodate the larger version. As soon as I get the larger version I will test it out and make another just for that.
But since they all have the same tools, the holder should work just fine.
I printed this thing as installed to minimize the amount of support material. Also I used 2 flat head #8 x 1.5" wood screws in conical anchors.

title: Printrbot Nozzle Adapter for Makerbot Printers

description.text: If you own a Makerbot and want to get in on the action of using the Printrbot nozzles that you can make using the Printrbot Nozzle Fabrication Toolbox at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53316, then check this out.

You can drill a 3/32" inch hole in a M6x1.0 male to 1/4"-20 male brass thread adapter (McMaster-Carr P/N 97437A600 found at http://www.mcmaster.com/#97437A600) like I've done in the photos. If the hole at the M6 end is a little off-center then you can use a larger drill bit to bevel the edges of the hole. Most likely the hole being off-center at the other end won't matter since there is still plenty of a path for the molten plasting to get the hole in the nozzle.

remixed_from.title: Safe and secure Raspberry Pi B+ Case

title: Safe and Secure Raspberry Pi 2 B Case

description.text:
This is another member in the Safe and Secure Raspberry Pi family of cases. It is a direct descendant of the B+ case I made not too long ago, and is meant to house a Raspberry Pi 2 B board. This model contains only 4 modifications compared to his ancestor. I simply made the countersunk holes for the screw heads bigger, by .25mm. The rest of the case is quite the same, with .2/.25mm tolerances. The tightness of the screws was the only complaint I received on the prior model, so it’s the only thing I changed. Since this new board will be able to run Windows 10, I also made a new top part with a Windows logo. If you are looking for the other case in this series, they can be found there: Original Raspberry Pi B:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:209100 Raspberry Pi B+:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:423216 Raspberry Pi A+:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:566506 Raspberry Pi 3 & 2 B:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1427797 Enjoy. Update, added new gpio top upon request. Update 2, added 40mm and 50mm fan top upon request. Update 3, many who print this case in ABS have said they printed the case at 101% of its size to account for shrinkage during ABS cooling. Update 4, added a 4mm longer plain bottom and plain top to remove access to the SD card from outside the case.

Choose a top and bottom part, and print them a .25 layer height.  
Use 4x M3 20mm socket head screws to secure the case together.

description.text:
It's a free swinging lamp on a broomstick. It can be installed on the side of a closet or on the wall. Because my room is too small I only created the mount to install it on a surface which is accessible from both sides.
If anyone wants a version to put the lamp on a wall just let me know and I will do my best to alter the mount.

Things you need:
  • broomstick (d=25mm max.)
  • bulb fitting
  • electric cable (use some fancy color :-)
  • nice, big lamp or a normal one with a lamp shade
  • switch, power plug
  • hook to screw into the wall or your closet
  • M4 screw and nut
  • 3d printed mount
    • Drill a hole (size of cable) into the top of the broomstick and another two holes at about 2/3 of the height at a distance of about 3cm. Connect the cable and the bulb fitting and direct the cable through the holes. Make a loop into the cable at whatever length you like. This loop is placed into the hook. Just try a couple of different length and distances of the mount and hook to find your perfect angle.

  • [EDIT: Don't do this, this wreaks havoc with your compass] Make a cutout and glue on some magnets onto your Bixler in the matching locations
  • [EDIT: Just wrap some rubber bands around everything to keep it on your bixler]
  • Cutout a little bit of foam from the aft end of the electronics mounting are of the Bixler to allow room for your servo connectors
  • Add some extra tape to anything if you feel it's necessary
  • Tape on the plastic cover that came with your Bixler

description.text: Flip-flop magnets: use as a decoration for a fridge or bulletin board. Please attached on the bottom using disc magnet of 1/2 X 1/8 inch size.

No more tears in your kitchen as from now on you will be hacking and slicing these annoying onions in seconds! Custom designed 4:1 involute planetary gearset and easy to grip bowl and ring gear for big torque capacity and blade speeds up to 340 rpm. No escaping these blades for your onions anymore! This fully 3d-printable onion cutter makes use of the fact that an M3 tap screw fits perfectly through the hole of 9mm stainless steel cutter blades. compared to it's functionality, it's a rather easy print:
  • no support needed
  • only small (11mm wide) bridges and some hole bridging
  • no overhangs above 45°
  • big bottom surface for good bed adhesion
  • no tweaking of the parts needed
  • small internal surfaces for correct hole bridging have been integrated in the parts
  • coordinate systems have been reoriented so parts are placed in correct printing orientation automatically
  • tolerances have been considered so parts do not have to be modified after print (except pushing out bridging in some holes), also print quality doesn't need to be perfect.
  • small edge chamfers have been added to the bottom side of the gears. Not only is this common in modern gear design, but it also makes up for over-squished first layers so you won't have to clean the teeth.
    • I managed to print this on my (poorly calibrated) Prism (a mendel derivate) with a damaged nozzle, uneven print bed and leaning problems and it still works like a charm!
    I had printer parts coming loose halfway through the print, filament clogging and still it works. So don't be scared by the sheer volume of the parts, you who own a makerbot should really have no problems, this is a very forgiving print.
    Total print time was ~10h with the bowl taking up almost half of it. I printed .3 layer height at 30mm/s so one might even be able to print it considerably faster. Total filament used was ~20m of 2.95mm PLA. The ring gear is glued into the shaft gear using a shaft-in-shaft bearing concept. You have the option to go for an easy version where the ring gear is only held in place by the planetary gears. For more information read the Instructions. demonstration of blade speed:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5T4PXQD87Pg
    proof that it works: =)
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kWxKJF94bA0

Vitamins needed:
1x ISO 4762 M3x50 tap screw (these are widely used in extruder idlers, f.i. Wade's, so you should have a spare)
1x ISO 4032 M3 nut
1x 608 bearing (most common bearing among printers)
4x 624 bearing (not that common although used in many extrusion frame printers, nevertheless they are so cheap so don't worry)
3x stainless steel cutter blades 9mm width, you can find them in your local hardware store or get them from amazon (you might even use normal steel, but then you have to clean the cutter immediately after use) Assembly instructions:

  • Print out all the parts

    • the shaft_gear_easy_print is not needed
    • Parts are designed for a layer height of .2 OR .3 mm or any dividor of either (e.g. .15, .1). DO NOT USE .25, .33, .4 or something like that or you might miss bridging layers
    • I suggest printing all parts at .3 layer height, 2 perimeters, 2 solid top/bottom layers and 20% honeycomb infill. I suggest printing the bowl with 3 solid TOP layers to ensure it is water-tight.
    • I suggest further to print all parts in PLA only as it is safe for food use.
    • The shaft should not be printed alone as the layers need time to cool and your bridges might droop, making the insertion of the blades impossible, so be sure to print it alongside the shaft gear
    • don't be fooled when printing the top part: the planetarys are NOT spaced 120deg each as the installation conditions are not met with the given tooth numbers. So dont worry if they do not line up with the gaps for snapping the bowl
    • i suggest reducing first layer spped for shaft_gear as it can prove quite of a challenge to your printer. If you're having trouble getting this printed, you can still go for shaft_gear_easy_print

  • Clean the parts

    • there isn't much cleaning needed as no support is used
    • push through all holes that use hole bridging, I use a hex key of the given size to do that
    • depending on how over-squished your first layer is, you might have to clean the teeth of the gearset. Use a sharp knife for that, maybe sanding will already be enough.
    • cut through the gaps in the shaft with a pointy, sharp and strong knife and make sure the cutter blades can be inserted
    • cut out the bridging layer in shaft_gear
  • Assembly
    • first, take the top part and push in a 608 and three 624 bearings
    • next, insert the shaft gear
    • break the blades so that they don't touch the bowl when inserted, yet come as close as possible to the rim of the bowl (maximum reasonably possible distance from the hole in the blades to the tip is 40mm)
    • insert the blades into the shaft in a way that they cut when the shaft turns counterclockwise (seen from above)
    • the blades will only fit in one orientation as the hole is not in the center of the blades
    • make sure the cutting edge faces the thicker side of the shaft (see sketch)
    • look through the shaft to make sure all holes align
    • insert an M3 nut into the shaft gear and the M3x50 screw into the shaft
    • place the shaft with the blades onto the square part of the shaft gear
    • screw the parts together so that they clamp onto the inner ring of the 608 bearing
    • put the three planetary gears in place
    • make sure the gears move smoothly
    • glue a 624 bearing in the shaft gear, add some glue to the pin of the ring gear and place the ring gear on top of the assembly
    • (If you went for shaft_gear_easy_print, break of the pin of the ring gear and just place the ring gear on top of the assembly, it will be held in place by the planetarys. The cutter will work with the shaft_gear_easy_print version but you might have the ring gear coming off when opening the bowl after cutting.) Use instructions:
  • peel and cut onions, insert into bowl
  • lock on the top
  • turn the ring gear and the bowl really fast against each other back and forth
  • enjoy your super small onions
  • empty and repeat for more onions
  • clean using cold water and soap only, do not put in dishwasher

title: Streamlight Sidewinder flashlight diffuser lens - lantern mod

description.text: A diffuser lens printed in clear PET plasic which fits onto the line of Streamlight SIdewinder flashlights. It's pictured on my Compact II, but should fit the heads of any of the models of Sidewinder lights. It turns the flashlight into a lantern which will light up a whole room at once. It just snaps onto the front of the flashlight. It's a tight fit and will not fall off. I have carried my light on my belt with the lens on it all day, no problems.

It MUST be printed out of crystal clear material. It looks white in the pictures because when clear plastic is layered in 3D printing, it refracts the light at each layer, giving that appearance. This makes it work very well as a diffuser lens! I used clear PET (soda bottle plastic) and I highly suggest it. PET filament can be bought online. It prints just like PLA, but it's VERY durable, and UV resistant. It's also safe to get gasoline or other fuels on it, even acetone. This is good if you're using it in a workshop where these things are present. I have included the .ipt file in case anyone has Autodesk Inventor and wants to edit it.

description.text:
At some point in life, you will want to connect wires to your Raspberry Pi's GPIO. You have a few options:
A) Make a tiny loop with your wire and hang it over the GPIO pin you want, and simultaneously hope that it doesn't become loose and destroy your RPi.
B) Use those female-to-male/female jumper cables typically found on amazon for 10+ cents a piece. Usually these are too loose for the pins on the RPi.
C) Find an old floppy disk ribbon cable (cheap but ugly) or get a GPIO ribbon cable from ebay (expensive but nice).
D) Print your own female-to-female GPIO connector (cheap and nice).

How do I use this?
1) Print this. It takes about 11 mins on my solidoodle 2.
2) Connect your wires to the correct positions on the connector you just printed.
3) Use hot glue to secure. (Better methods probably exist). Let me know if you find any.
4) Put connector + attached wires on your RPi.
5) Be awesome. Files:
  • As usual, use the STL. (Units are in mm as usual).
  • I used blender to make this, and the blend file is included just in case you wanna improve it.
  • If you have a solidoodle 2, I have also included the gcode i used to print this. Feel free to use this at your own risk. (Slic3r, 0.3mm, other details at beginning of gcode).

title: Ormerod Extruder Drive Block Bowden tube clamp

description.text: Fed up with the tongue coming out and the Bowden tube coming adrift ruining prints I modified the extruder body to stop this happening.

Parts needed;  
Bowden End from Components RepRapPro shop with 5mm end thread.  
Tapered Brass M5 nut from RepRapPro shop.  
M3x14 skt hd bolt 2-off.  
M3 Nut 2-off.  
Extra length of 3mm PTFE sleeving.  
Unscrew existing Bowden Start,place clamp over end of Bowden tube,then screw on Bowden End so that it is tight,ream inside of tube with a 2mm drill as original Ormerod instructions to achieve alignment,screw on tapered nut and firmly tighten.assemble onto extruder block and then insert filament manually to make sure of a smooth passage.  
I have used this for several months with no problems and you do not need to unscrew the clamp when changing filament  
Acknowledgement to Mr Burns(RepRap forums) for the originally modified extruder block using the longer PTFE sleeve.

title: Raspberry Pi Case Camera Mount for 15mm Open Beam OB1515

description.text:
Example timelapse printing video, a function in OctoPi (OctoPrint). Raspberry Pi camera set to HD and mounted on print bed:
https://youtu.be/1Q_HYHBMtgM The above video was shot using my LED bar lights, build your own for less than 6 bucks!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1398522 Raspberry Pi case with camera case and adjustable mount. Links can be added to the camera mount arm to extend it as desired. The case includes mount holes and boss for attached directly to Open Beam OB1515 extrusion material. Designed for use with OctoPi (OctoPrint), recommend using the new quad core Raspberry Pi 2 board, B+ board will also fit in this case. Complete directions, OctoPi image download link/info, best Raspberry Pi 2 prices, and updates at BigCooter.com link: http://bigcooter.com/?p=1442 A simple LED light pipe can be made from bending a translucent piece of 1.75mm filament, and stuffing into housing hole. Upper Case & parts made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/guyw6v1ZJTw Lower Case & parts made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7ZGF2xiv0pu Print with no support, 15% infill, PLA or ABS. Threaded holes: drill 2.5mm / tap M3. Screw clearance holes: drill 3.0 to 3.3mm diameter. The Raspberry Pi camera does have a factory preset focus distance that is not optimized for this application. A more macro focus can be achieved by simply turning the camera lens 1/3 to 3/4 turn CCW. Note that these lens are glued in position at factory, a small exacto knife using magnification can help release the glue, or just brute force turning with quality needle nose pliers can get it done - just be careful. Optional: mount camera directly on print bed, with RPi case or separate with long cable see photo. Video of Lower Case parts plate printing, using this camera with OctoPi Timelapse, with camera lens refocused (1/3 turn CCW): https://youtu.be/OnvyQCy9Brc Pi case Remixed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:465678

comments.author: LizQuilty

comments.text:
Hello LizQuilty,
I uploaded the STL, but it is not unified. Depending on your software you may have to unify the model with another software or use something like netfabb or meshlab.
The part is not printable without support, thus the gear and the frame will be fused by support material. It took me an hour to Scrape it out using wood working knifes.
If you use a 3d printer with water soluble support material this will be no issue, else turning this model into parts to assemble after printing may be the best way to go. If you need help with that let me know and I will make another revision.
When I first got my printer I tried printing these kind of mechanical things, trying to figure out what my 3D printer can print pre-assembled. It's a fascinating technology, but things like these hit certain limits when it comes to single-material extruders ;-)

https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/2097483958/keystone For assembling this you will need print file keystone_simple.
If you have regular keys, in file keystone_inserts you will find inserts for the keyholes, because screw for assembling is smaller than hole in key. If you have some keys not standard format, you will need to create your own insert, but this is not necessary. It only prevents keys being wobbly on the screw. Next you will need two screws M4 and two matrixes M4. Also a lot of washers between keys and on both sides of inside. For assembling start with two screws inserted in one of keystone parts - it is the one with rounded holes. Next insert washer on each screw. Then insert key with insert, then washer and repeat this until you have keys left. On end insert one washer for space between last key and keystone ending. Then insert keystone ending - it is one with hexagonal holes. Then add matrixes, arrange them to level with actual holes in keystone and start tightening the screws. You can arrange your keys your way, but I recommend you to insert at least one washer between each key. If you have same usb as I have, you could print keystone_usb_kingston_datatravelerSE9 too.

description.text: These are 1/10 scale traffic cones I use with my R/C drift cars.  I drew   them up to include a realistic looking base for more scale detail.

This was my first attempt at printing multiple colors by pausing the print and swapping filament colors. To get a clean sharp color swap first
pause your print then quickly jog the Z up about 30mm to get the hot nozzle off the part. Then swap the filament color. Purge out about 100 mm to clean the old color out of the extruder and get the new color primed an ready to go. Hit resume print and wait for the next color swap. I printed these from Hatchbox PLA at 208 deg. on a Printrbot metal simple using Slicer and Repatier host software. The parts were modeled in AutoCAD.

A common requirement is to add ranging to a Pixy so you can detect an object and determine it's distance.  This is a bracket to firmly mount the commonest types of ultrasonic sensor below the Pixy lens.

The bracket was designed for the US-100 ultrasonic sensor shown in the images. It also fits the SRF05 which has a slightly shorter and thicker PCB.  The file for this is US_Bracket-A.  
The HC-SR04 has components closer to the PCB edge and file US_Bracket-B shortens one of the guides to allow for this. (I haven't printed the 'B' off but it should hold secure enough.)  
Insert the sensor from the top before sliding the bracket onto the Pixy to butt against the lens body.  The sensor connector does partially cover the Pixy LED, but if this is a problem in your application remove the header and wire direct to the sensor PCB.

My original printer was made from components salvaged from a 1980's xray copier. Great stuff but way too much mass for quick printing. So I am building up a H bot with MakerSlide. This will have a lot less moving mass.
The H bot requires six pulleys to guide the belt around the figure H. I created a simple bracket that fits in the 20mm t slot. I designed in a nut holder but I put it at the wrong orientation so it won'f fit in the slot as is. Rather than reprint, I just put a 6-32 screw and nut in the track to prevent the bracket from moving in the slot. It fits pretty tight already but there will be belt tension so it should have a mechanical fastener. I used 10-24 machine screw with some washers to ensure clearance to hold the pulley. The Inventables pulley I used has a slight interior ridge on one side which prevents the bearings from centering. I filed off this ridge and used one washer on each side. I uploaded a single bracket and a set of five. Make sure your single looks good and then print the rest. UPDATE: I took a file to my original set of brackets. If you are going to make these, I suggest making the embedded nut deeper so it fits the slot and countersinking the screw hole that connects the slot nut. For belt clearance the slot screw needs to have a flat head. I would also put a circular bump on the inside of the bracket so it doesn't need washers. And if the bracket sides were a little thicker it could have an embedded nut for the bolt going through the pulley.

title: LG G watch R / Urbane charging device holder - Simple, quick print

description.text:
This is a holder for the round LG watch charging puck. It allows you to easily charge your watch even if you have a watch band with a deployment buckle, or folding clasp. The model is designed so it prints in around an hour. You can also take it apart again so it doesn't use up any space when travelling. I think this will also fit the newer LG Urbane series because the charger part looks very similar to the one LG G watch R comes with.  
The two parts are also downloadable separately, to make it easier to print separately in different colours.

I printed this in PLA which works great. Use your favorite settings. Slide the parts together, use an X-acto if needed to make the perfect fit. Insert the charging puck so the micro-USB port is accessible on the left side. If the charging puck seems like a tight fit, remove one or two of the small knobs inside the flanges until they hold the puck well.

This is a ground up design for E3D-v6 'metal only' hotend mount on K8200. You can reuse the heater element and temperature sensor. Unlike other versions, this mount has two sections, locking the mount from both sides, and can be further secured with screws. I would recommend all K8200 user who are still stuck with the 0.5mm nozzle to upgrade to this. Note: you will need new longer (>30mm) m3 screws to mount this onto the extruder unit plus a 30mm 12V fan (tie supply this to the hotend supply) and 14mm M2 screws to secure the fan This is obviously a better design than the rest because it is designed by a girl... Happy Women's Day!

comments.text:
I just bought the e3D hotend and am looking at the mounts but have two electrical questions:
1) It seems you connected the fan to the hot end supply. This is PID controlled so did you have problems with the fan while the PWM of the PID was going?
2) When the thermistor reaches the target temperature, the heater switches off. If the fan is connected in parallel to the heater, do you worry about the heat of the block and nozzle raising the temperature of the heat sink just after the hot end supply is switched off? The feedback will keep the nozzle at a constant temperature but the temperature of the heat sink could fluctuate as the fan turns on and off? Without measuring the temp, I have no guess if it is a problem. Maybe the heat sink is so efficient, the fan is not totally necessary??
comments.author: eightbitguy

comments.text: Yes I did have performance issues tying the fan to hot-end supply, the PID introduce a larger ripple on the set temperature, eventually I simply left it on all the time, permanently tied to the 15V supply with a On/Off switch.
comments.author: eightbitguy

comments.text:
Thank you! That makes sense. Did you do the PID auto tune that is suggested for the Marlin firmware? I received the head yesterday and have started thinking about how to mount it...
My K8200, with it's current extruder doesn't bridge very well. In what orientation did you print your parts? The smaller piece looks pretty obvious but the part that the fan mounts to seems to want to be printed fan-side down... Is that how you printed it? Anyways, I'm excited!
comments.author: CorrugatorSupercilii

comments.text: Yes fan side down on heat bed, 100% infill, if you're using Cura, ignore K8200 nozzle size of 0.5mm, slice with 0.4mm, shell thickness at least 0.8mm

comments.text: Thank you, again! I switched from Linux to a Mac so I have been using Repetier Host 0.56 on my Macbook Air but not been happy with the print quality. My Linux laptop is running Debian 8 and the FTDI driver is causing crashes. Also I wasn't sure which version of Repetier host to use. There were some compatibility issues on the K8200 site so I never spent the time to see which version actually works. I installed OctoPi about a week ago but have been doing the the slicing with Slic3r 1.2.9 on the Mac and send the geode files. I know OctoPi uses the Cura engine to slice but I can't see where it's getting its configuration from, so I haven't trusted it, yet. Basically my setup is a wreck and I'm hoping the e3D fixes a lot of basic issues... The X-Y plane of the K8200 seems to be working well. No strange jumps or losing steps. Z has the K8204 upgraded threaded rod but none of the modified stepper motor mounts.  I beefed up the heated bed power supply to 24V with an opto-triac switch turning on and off a 24V AC transformer. I was rectifying it but thought simpler is better and removed the bridge rectifier.

description.text: This little piece slides into the flash socket on the Sony A6000 camera to hold the flash up.  This allows the flash to bounce off the ceiling instead of hitting the person directly.  A bounced flash produces a less harsh image.  Obviously no support is needed, and normal fill levels are fine.  The hole allows you to hook it to your camera or lens cap strap so it is always there when you need it.  It may work on other Sony cameras providing the flash design and socket position are similar.  To use it, pop up the flash and hold it back with your finger, slide the piece into the flash socket and then rotate until it holds back the flash on its own.

title: Domino generator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Make your own set (28 pieces) of domino's to cut in with a laser cutter. Also check out this laser cut box that holds a set of domino including the rule block: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:714648

Preparing the files:

  • If you just want to make the premade set that I uploaded then just skip the rest of this step.

    • If you want to generate your own set then just complete the following steps:
  • Find a black and white image that you want for the "dots" on the pieces and prepare it for engraving (see skull.ai)
  • Open the excel and search and replace the "exactPath" with the path for your image
  • Export the excel as a Text (tab delimited) file
  • Open the inDesign file and adjust the size of the page to fit your cutting piece
  • Relink the data merge file in the inDesign file with the new file you made
  • Now use the data merge function to generate your domino's
    • If you want to customise it more than this then make your desired changes in the master page. Preparing to cut:

  • Choose the material that you want to use.
    Cover it in masking tape to prevent the gas created when cutting to color the pieces.

    • Create:

  • Cut the pieces with the appropriate amount of Pew Pew

    • Finishing:

  • Adding some color to the pattern can help make a bigger contrast when using material such as clear acrylic. If you want to color the patterns that you engraved in the pieces then it can in some cases be easier to color them before removing the masking tape.

    • I also added a file for the making a larger piece with the rules for blocking domino

description.text:
A fully parametric and 99.9% printable box with a magnetic lid.  
For pencils, glasses, tools, pills, toys, milling bits, phones, components, insects, USB-sticks, Tesa, sewing cotton, batteries, dust, TEK 7000 plugins, eggs, nerf darts, butter cookies, drills, motors, transistors, toy cars, cables, in-ear phones, plugs, brains, bass strings, knobs, spoons, small vise collections, watches, chewing gum, lenses, tapes, magnets, fingers, lasers, and, and, and...
LOAD

Open the provided "PencilBox_Vxy.scad" file with OpenSCAD and set the first four parameters like this: PRINTBOT = 1; // 0/1 turn bottom part off/on
PRINTTOP = 1; // 0/1 turn top part (lid) off/on
PRINTPOS = 0; // 0/1 move lid in printing position
SHOWOFFPOS = 1; // 0/1 nice looking off/on; This will show the box with the lid open. MODIFY

Tune all parameters until the box matches your needs. Hints:
  • If the lid suddenly "leaves" the box, check "hiHeight".
  • "hiDia" is the diameter of the hinge hole.
      Make sure it is a little larger than your filament diameter.
  • Make sure to enter the right magnet size settings.
  • Pay attention to the grip parameters too.
      These are not absolute values but relative scaling factors.
    • EXPORT

If you are happy with the results, set PRINTBOT = 1; // 0/1 turn bottom part off/on
PRINTTOP = 0; // 0/1 turn top part (lid) off/on
PRINTPOS = 1; // 0/1 move lid in printing position
SHOWOFFPOS = 0; // 0/1 nice looking off/on; export the bottom part.
To save the lid, set PRINTBOT = 0; // 0/1 turn bottom part off/on
PRINTTOP = 1; // 0/1 turn top part (lid) off/on PRINT

Print warp-free ;-)  
PREPARE

You will need:
  • both printed parts, bottom and top (lid)
  • 2 x a bit of filament as hinge pins
  • 4 x magnet
    • Put a little glue into the four magnet slots and check the orientation of the magnets.
    Then, check the orientation of the magnets.
    Then, check the orientation of the magnets.
    Then, check the orientation of the magnets.
    After checking the magnet orientation a fifth time, press them into
    the slots and wait until the glue has dried. Align the bottom and top part and insert a bit of filament into the hinge holes on each side.
    Cut away the excess filament down to ~0.5mm and use a soldering iron to fix the hinge pin. USE

• Pack all your stuff in the box.
  • Move the box to another place.
  • Flip the box over.
  • Open it.
  • Blame it on your children.
    • CHANGES
• V1.2: added missing grip size modifiers

A knife box (block) to organize your knives.  Can sit on the counter or attach to the wall.  Modular design to accommodate varying knife sizes.

The box is printed in 2 pieces and joined by a set of tabs used to guide the two halves together. The box halves will need to be sliced with the thin walls option enabled. print the following for the basic box:
Knife_holder_top_half
Knife_holder_bottom_half
knife_holder_rails
knife_holder_image_plate
tab_connector print your desired mods (create your own using the scad file)
included are:
knife_holder_chef_flat_mod.stl - for chefs knives that have a handle that is 90 degrees to the top of the blade.
knife_holder_chef_sloped_mod.stl - for chefs knives with a slightly sloped handle design.
knife_holder_long_mod - for knives with blades longer than the height of the box.
knife_holder_short_mod - for knives that need additional blade support.
knife_holder_rail_cap - can be used to cap off the top of the rail system. Spacers to fill gaps for included modules:
Spacer_5 - 5mm for knife_holder_chef_flat_mod
Spacer_9_8 - 9.8mm for knife_holder_chef_sloped_mod
Spacer_25_3 - 25.3mm for knife_holder_short_mod or knife_holder_long_mod. the rail system snaps into the top half of the box, and the image plate goes on the front of the box. Use super glue where needed, if needed.

Designed for the Countertop Challenge The Countertop Tea Chest provides a decorative and convenient place to store your favorite teas. The Tea Chest includes has an open area on one side for tea bags and two internal containers that can be used for loose tea and/or for sugar cubes. Or you can simply use the chest without the containers to store your favorite tea K-Cups or pods. A pair of tongs store in the lid of the chest. The lid hinge is oversize for durability and uses a piece of 1.75mm printer filament for the hinge pin. The Tea Chest also features unique flip latch on the front. The flip latch lever is also held in place with a short length of 1.75mm printer filament. I'll add photos of a printed version when it's complete.

I'm printing my prototypes in ABS but PLA will work fine also.
The STL files are already oriented for optimum printing.
The parts do require breakaway support but I've tried to reduce it as much as possible. Refer to the photos for assembly. Enjoy!

title: Tablet Mount for Shower or Wall

description.text:
This is a wall mount for a tablet or phone, specifically designed to fit the Sony Xperia Z3 Tablet Compact.  This will work for other tablets or phones that are less than 8mm thick. with a 6mm or greater side bevel.  
I made this mount for use in the shower, but it could be used on any wall.

This is designed to print upwards as the file is oriented. the holes for the hooks are 5mm in diameter. If you are mounting this on a slick surface such as shower tile or glass, I would recommend these cheap and good quality suction cups: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000FA6CIE This mount is thicker on the bottom than the top so that the tablet leans back against it. The protrusions on the bottom back part are to hold the bottom of the mount out far enough from the wall. If you use other hooks than the suction cups linked here, make sure they don't protrude from the wall more than 14mm. Remember to use all three hook holes so that your tablet remains on the wall in case one fails, especially if using suction cups.

comments.text: I had been trying to print with PLA over the course of weeks, each time I tried it would work for a bit, then the filaments being extruded would turn to "cotton candy" and not stick to anything. I noticed that many posts said to use oil with PLA, but they never said it was to prevent the filament from turning wispy. I kept thinking the oil was to stop the filament from jamming completely, and jamming was not my problem. FINALLY I put 2 and 2 together and printed this oiler in ABS. I used piece of white cosmetic sponge (note that some cosmetic sponges are "oil repellent", don't get those!), just enough that when folded in half it makes contact with the filament passing through, and used canola oil.

remixed_from.title: Toyota 4 Cylinder Engine 22RE, Complete working model

title: Working 5 speed transmission model for Toyota 22RE engine

description.text:
All my models are printed on a Prusa i3 kit. You can find the one I use by clicking the link below. You can get 15% off by using code "GBTE"
Tronxy Prusa I3 This is the 5 speed transmission that comes bolted to the back of a 22RE. This is the 4WD version of the transmission so it has a mounting surface to bolt a transfer case to. The transfer case will be the next thing I will upload Fully working. All 5 speeds plus reverse. It uses a good amount of 3mm rod and 623zz bearings. M2.5 x 5mm set screws and nuts were used due to the small size of some of the parts. http://youtu.be/SB34I33Bqrg

Update: 03/16/2015
Updated assembly drawings Update: 03/15/2015
Shift linkage.stl file updated for more clearance. The old one will still work you just might have to modify it, Update: 03/12/2015
Transmission housing cover 1 had a problem with the source file not laying flat. New file has been uploaded.
Thanks pointing this out RossRobotics The assembly diagrams are not that great. This model is more complex than the engine and is pretty much one giant assembly so it's hard to convey that through multiple assembly diagrams. There are a bunch of photos showing the parts and the locations but assembling this will take a little bit of know how. You will have to figure out which holes to drill, ream, and tap. There's not too many of them. Any questions, just ask. See excel spread sheet for parts list, descriptions, and notes about parts. Most parts will require a Brim to prevent curling. There is a test jig to print out to see if your gears mesh properly before you put everything together. If you're finding that your gears are too tight you can file the teeth down or scale the gears down in the X and Y directions a small percentage. Do not scale the Z. You can also scale up if you're finding that they are too tight.
I made the fit on the gears pretty loose so you should be able to just print them and go but it depends on your printer. There are also three holes on the side of Transmission housing 2. These can be tapped and you can insert a ball/spring/set screw into them as well as make a groove on the shift shaft to make a detent so that each shaft is held in the neutral position. It helps keep the transmission from going into random gears while shifting or locking up due to two gears being engaged at the same time. You will need to reprint the new engine stand or modify your current start so the transmission can mate to the engine. For the hardware i still recommend boltdepot.com but amazon has pretty decent prices for packs of 100 for socket products. The 3mm rod that is made by Amico on Amazon works great. Fits the bearings perfectly and is cheaper than the tool steel I recommended previously. If you buy the 10 pack of 150mm x 3mm or 200mm x 3mm rods then you will have more than enough. http://www.amazon.com/Stainless-Steel-200x3mm-Transmission-Airplane/dp/B00FHMAIHQ/ref=sr_1_7?ie=UTF8&qid=1425864242&sr=8-7&keywords=3mm+rod If you find any issues with the files or assembly diagrams please let me know by commenting or private message.

comments.text: I sourced balls from amazon. They need to be about 2.5mm. Small enough to fit through a threaded 3mm hole. The springs i got from inside a toggle switch. I marked the shift rod by assembling the whole transmission and using a small drill bit to put a small mark on each shift rail while it was in neutral, 1st, 2nd etc. I then used a round file to make the detent. You can also get small m3 ball detents off of ebay. I think the assembly diagrams I made may have the rough dimension of the shift detent location but I may be mistaken.

comments.text: If this helps. I have a R2X and i print plenty in PLA but  when i use PLA i do 192c and 37c and a 58mm cooling fan lightly blowing on the print , about 1 foot away from the print. Blue tape and door open .On larger prints i take the lid off also. The only reason i did ABS is an over stock of filament ,5 rolls of orange  and to many rolls of other ABS. So i printed the gears solid but even then i used some cooling so the bottom did not swell. But printing solid was really over kill . The model is perfect so , ABS or PLA will print nicely .
comments.author: Aceric

comments.text: Everything was PLA, One use printed everything in ABS and it came out fine. I believe he has a MakerBot.  The gears and the shift linkage are the only things that really should be printed in high resolution, higher infill, and more perimeters And they should be printed in PLA if you plan on running the thing constantly as a display. And if your printer can print ABS, its should be able to print PLA just fine. Maybe just add a cooling fan.  My setting for everything except the gears was 3 perimeters, 3 bottom layers, 4 top layers, 30% infill, 60m/s speed, and .2mm layer height.  But it all depends on your printer, how long you're willing to wait for your part to print, and the quality you desire. Here is a link to the transmission made with ABS.
comments.author: Aceric

comments.text: Yeah, I can't just print PLA with the replicator 2x, I have to make some modifications to have active cooling. That's what I was referring to when I said I'd have to wait till I upgrade the printer if I do decide to use PLA. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:221306 is the mod I'm looking at.

comments.text: I know he printed the engine in ABS from talking to him personally. I can only assume that the transmssion is also. comments.text:
Hello Eric,
Congratulations on another successful design!
Regarding respecting this design's CC non-commercial license- A friend without a 3D printer has inquired about me printing one for him.
Would you consider him paying me for time and materials to print one a violation? This is more than a "favor to friend" type of print.
What if he pays to print one for him?
What if he buys a printer from me to print it? I'd be happy to sell him one, making about as much money.
I'd hope that the primary uses that would offend you would be someone production printing and selling copies, or using it as an advertisement (many websites ARE getting traffic off it..)
Hopefully this comes across as genuinely trying to understand and respect your wishes about the use of your design that you've put tremendous effort into. Thanks again!

comments.author: Kepler20b

comments.text: I changed out the motor to a 12V 120RPM motor so that I could power the transmission without a problem.  The original 3v motor will still work with the transmission attached, it's just slower.  I wanted the electric motor and batteries to be self contained hence the smaller motor. I will upload the modified compressor housing that fits the 12V motor but the battery location will be left to the user. As for a starter motor, that was the original plan to drive the engine but after careful thought I decided against it due to the high speed required from the motor which would probably lead to premature wear of the drive gear.

description.text: CVSS Logo

Designed to be a snug fit for the Eagle Tree Vector flight controller. Mounted with glue or similar to EPO fuselage. I'm using a 20mm wide velcro strap (shorter than the one in the pictures..) that was placed around the mounting pad before I glued it to the fuselage. The 20mm*2mm opening under the mounting pad makes it possible to mount it flat even with a velcro strap around it. USB and all connectors are availiable when fitted.

Due to the 20mm*2mm opening under the mounting pad you have to use support material. I used the same support material as I printed the rest in and it was easy to remove it after printing. Used default settings in slic3r and made it so it filled from z=0mm. Printed in PLA with fan cooling.

description.text:
The Living Environment Module is a modular building block that can be used to construct various furniture pieces such as the side table shown. L.E.M. captures the juxtaposition of the ever-growing separation between the personal manufacturing (3D printing) market and the history of handmade wood furniture. Be sure to show off your work using #lemfurniture!  
See the full project at www.omar-gonzalez.com/lem

I used the low res setting with each piece printed individually, on its side, and with raft.
I used a bandsaw to cut out each wooden piece along with a milling machine to punch out the holes for the connectors.
